image.altText: Two women with umbrellas walk past the Reserve Bank building.

items.synopsis: Treasurer Jim Chalmers is adamant that his budget will not make inflation worse and force the Reserve Bank's hand on interest rates — but economists are divided.

title.children: What does the federal budget mean for inflation and interest rates?

image.altText: Treasurer Jim Chalmers delivers the budget speech.

items.synopsis: A series of measures aimed at tackling the cost-of-living crisis have been delivered as part of this year's federal budget. Follow the live updates.

title.children: Cost-of-living relief measures met with mixed response as Treasurer delivers budget

schema.headline: Federal budget 2023 live: Cost-of-living relief measures met with mixed response as Treasurer Jim Chalmers delivers budget

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Voice debate having a 'difficult impact' on Indigenous Australians
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: "There's money there for the referendum which is right because we have a referendum coming up but also $10.5 million in mental health support for Indigenous Australians in the referendum period. What does that say about the impact that this debate is having on First Nations people?" News Breakfast host Michael Rowland asks. "Well, it is having a difficult impact," Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says. "There are words that are used these days on social media and in other forms often anonymous, sometimes not frankly, some of the things that are being said in this debate are hurtful. "We're very conscious of the pressure which Indigenous Australians will be under. We know that when the vote, the postal ballot was held on marriage equality, then people in that community felt under pressure as well and we have been conscious about that."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: PM pressed on difference between cost-of-living package and stage 3 tax cuts
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: "Stage three tax cuts will cost $69 billion over four years, our cost of living package comes in at $15 billion. Can you see how some people out there perhaps more than some people would see a massive disconnect?" Michael Rowland asks. "Well, they, of course, were legislated some time ago. They're included in the budget as they have been for some time and we have no plans to change those measures. We haven't given consideration to that," Prime Minister Anthony Albanese replies. "Do you see how some people see $69 billion for tax cuts targeting in large part wealthy Australians compared to only $15 billion for cost of living?" Rowland repeats. "Those measures begin at $45,000, if you're on $45,000, watching this program, you don't regard yourself as being wealthy," Albanese replies.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: 'We got the balance right': PM responds to JobSeeker criticism
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: "Independent Senator David Pocock describes that as both laughable and embarrassing. Are you to offer any such a small rise in JobSeeker?" Michael Rowland asks the prime minister. "There's a great contradiction you put in the first two issues you raised with me," Anthony Albanese says. "You said we're spending too much in your first question, and the second you say we're not spending enough. The truth is we got the balance right. "We understand that people are under pressure, but we needed to make sure that it was a responsible budget so this $40 increase is something that will make a difference to people."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Budget 'takes pressure off families whilst not putting pressure on inflation', PM says
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is currently speaking to Michael Rowland on News Breakfast. Rowland : "$20 billion in new spending, is that really going to help force the inflation dragon back into its cave?" Albanese : "$40 billion of savings over two budgets, 87% of the revenue gains put to the bottom line unlike our predecessors where the number was 40% or the Howard government where the number was 30%. This is a budget that takes pressure off families whilst not putting pressure on inflation."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: How hard is it for uni students to live off Youth Allowance?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Before this year's budget, the highest rate a single, childless person on Youth Allowance could receive was around $14,600 a year — so how hard is it to live off the welfare payment? The ABC's Shalailah Medhora has more 👇

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Chalmers pressed on stage 3 tax cuts
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: "You revealed the cost of the stage 3 tax cuts will be $69 billion over four years, four times the cost-of-living package. What is right about that picture?" News Breakfast presenter Michael Rowland asks Treasurer Jim Chalmers. "I was asked yesterday how much they'd cost and because there's an extra year of these cuts in the forward estimates, it's a bigger number than it was last name," Chalmers said. "You can see the disparity between the figures and how that would be viewed by people. "First of all, those tax cuts kick in at $45,000 and it's important that we give back some of the bracket creep in the jargon, particularly to people on low and middle incomes, but we haven't changed our position on the stage 3 tax cuts. "What we've done in the budget last night is to provide some help for people who are doing it toughest, the most vulnerable people in our community and that shows where our priorities are. "We haven't changed our position. They don't come in for more than a year now. They haven't actually been a focus of the deliberations for this budget at all."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Chalmers explains reason for changing JobSeeker age threshold
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: In case you missed it: The higher JobSeeker rate for older people, which previously applied to recipients over 60 who had received JobSeeker for 9 months or longer, will now apply for recipients over 55. It means people aged 55 to 59 will receive an additional $92.10 per fortnight above what they receive today. Treasurer Jim Chalmers says "it's a really important change." "One of the most concerning parts of the community of Australians who can't find works is over-55s and particularly women over 55 ," he told News Breakfast. "The advice that we receive from the expert committees we set up is that this is a big and growing challenge for us. It is harder and harder, particularly for women over 55, to get back into work. Big increases in homelessness and the like and we've tried to provide extra help there."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Is that JobSeeker increase the best a wealthy country can do?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: That's the question that's just been posed to Treasurer Jim Chalmers. The JobSeeker base rate is increasing to $40 a fortnight, which breaks down to an extra $2.85 a day. "We've tried to do as much as we can without blowing the budget and adding substantially to inflationary pressures in the economy," Chalmers told News Breakfast. "I understand and respect that there will be people who say that we should do more. There will be people who say we shouldn't have done any of this. "We've done what we can and also a lot of people who are eligible for one of these payment increases in the budget would be eligible for two or more of these increases. "You need to look across the cost-of-living package."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Chalmers calls budget surplus a 'complex balancing act'
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: "We've got this big improvement in revenues in the near term and we've taken the most responsible approach to that and that's why we're forecasting a surplus for this year," he told News Breakfast. "But we've got some structural challenges in the budget. We made a heap of progress on those last night. But there will be more work to do. And again, as you said before, what we've been able to do on the foundations of a much more responsible and much stronger budget is to provide help for people doing it tough at the same time as we invest in the future."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Find out if you're among the budget's winners or losers
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Treasurer Jim Chalmers has handed down his second budget, which looks good for the government, but what is in it for you? Have a look at this cheat sheet of what's set to receive more funding — and who will be paying for it.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Bandt says extra JobSeeker money 'not enough to buy a loaf of bread'
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Greens leader Adam Bandt says the extra $2.85 a day for JobSeeker is "not enough to buy a loaf of bread". "Labor promised no-one would be left behind. The budget leaves millions of people behind, giving tax cuts to the politicians and billionaires while every day people on Jobseeker are left in poverty," he told ABC News Breakfast. Bandt added that "5.5 million renters get absolutely nothing out of this budget". "Those lucky to get rent assistance might get a dollar a day. Rents in capital cities have been growing 10 times faster than that. "Labor doesn't understand how severe the rental and housing crisis is. People are sleeping in tents and cars. People are spending 60 per cent of their income on rents."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: $40 per fortnight for JobSeeker 'clearly not enough', ACOSS CEO says
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Cassandra Goldie, the chief executive of the Australian Council of Social Service, says the $40 per fortnight increase to JobSeeker is "clearly not enough". "Every dollar for somebody on a very low income will make a difference but it is not enough," she told ABC News Breakfast. "We still today have a JobSeeker unemployment payment which is a poverty payment. It is one of the lowest in the OECD and we need to get it to where it should be."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Could we see another interest rate rise because of the federal budget?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Treasurer Jim Chalmers is adamant his second budget will not make Australia's inflation problem worse, while providing cost of living relief — but economists are divided about whether that confidence is misplaced. Some economists have even suggested the budget was a "missed opportunity" for the treasurer to do more to cut inflation and put an end to rate rises by the Reserve Bank. You can continue reading this story by business reporter Kate Ainsworth below.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: BCA chief says government delivered 'solid budget' but opportunities were missed
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Business Council of Australia CEO Jennifer Westacott says a budget surplus "gives confidence to markets and resilience in the future", but there were missed opportunities on multiple fronts. "The issue is it is a missed opportunity to tackle productivity and investment which will give you stronger budgets and a more sustainable surplus in the longer term," she told ABC News Breakfast. She aded there was another missed opportunity to tackle the structural deficit. "Business did all the heavy lifting last night and there is nothing to drive our investment against the backdrop of other countries who are pushing hard into this. "The hard work is fixing and reforming government services. By that, not cost cutting but going to digital services, getting improved outcomes for people, making sure we slow the rate of growth in these services, that they are efficient and effective for people and fix all of the issues in our federation."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Didn't catch the budget last night? Here's what you need to know
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: If you weren't up frantically refreshing the blog all night (unlikely), here are a few of the key announcements you should know about: There will be $14.6 billion of cost-of-living relief, including help with power bills, reduced health costs and creating more affordable housing The government is allocating $11.3 billion to provide aged care workers with an interim increase of 15 per cent to award wages An extra $40 per fortnight will be delivered for J obSeeker, youth allowance and Austudy recipients Bulk-billing incentives will be tripled for the most common consultations with children under the age of 16, pensioners and other Commonwealth concession card holders The maximum rate of Commonwealth Rent Assistance will be increased by 15 per cent

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Good morning!
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Welcome to today's live blog, where we'll be unpacking last night's budget. Stick with us as we bring you the latest reactions, interviews and analysis from around the ABC.

liveBlogStreamPrepared.name: Federal budget 2023 live: Cost-of-living relief measures met with mixed response as Treasurer Jim Chalmers delivers budget

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Treasurer Jim Chalmers is adamant his second budget will not make Australia's inflation problem worse, while providing cost of living relief — but economists are divided about whether that confidence is misplaced. Some economists have even suggested the budget was a "missed opportunity" for the treasurer to do more to cut inflation and put an end to rate rises by the Reserve Bank. You can continue reading this story by business reporter Kate Ainsworth below.

children.content: (AAP: Bianca De Marchi)
Treasurer
Jim Chalmers
is adamant his second
budget will not make Australia's inflation problem worse, while providing cost of living relief —
but economists are divided about whether that confidence is misplaced.
Some economists
have even suggested the budget was a "missed opportunity" for the treasurer to do more to cut inflation and put an end to rate rises by the Reserve Bank.

Kate Ainsworth
below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Business Council of Australia CEO Jennifer Westacott says a budget surplus "gives confidence to markets and resilience in the future", but there were missed opportunities on multiple fronts. "The issue is it is a missed opportunity to tackle productivity and investment which will give you stronger budgets and a more sustainable surplus in the longer term," she told ABC News Breakfast. She aded there was another missed opportunity to tackle the structural deficit. "Business did all the heavy lifting last night and there is nothing to drive our investment against the backdrop of other countries who are pushing hard into this. "The hard work is fixing and reforming government services. By that, not cost cutting but going to digital services, getting improved outcomes for people, making sure we slow the rate of growth in these services, that they are efficient and effective for people and fix all of the issues in our federation."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: BCA chief says government delivered 'solid budget' but opportunities were missed

She aded there was another missed opportunity to tackle the structural deficit.
"Business did all the heavy lifting last night and there is nothing to drive our investment against the backdrop of other countries who are pushing hard into this.

"The hard work is fixing and reforming government services. By that, not cost cutting but going to digital services, getting improved outcomes for people, making sure we slow the rate of growth in these services, that they are efficient and effective for people and fix all of the issues in our federation."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you weren't up frantically refreshing the blog all night (unlikely), here are a few of the key announcements you should know about: There will be $14.6 billion of cost-of-living relief, including help with power bills, reduced health costs and creating more affordable housing The government is allocating $11.3 billion to provide aged care workers with an interim increase of 15 per cent to award wages An extra $40 per fortnight will be delivered for J obSeeker, youth allowance and Austudy recipients Bulk-billing incentives will be tripled for the most common consultations with children under the age of 16, pensioners and other Commonwealth concession card holders The maximum rate of Commonwealth Rent Assistance will be increased by 15 per cent
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Didn't catch the budget last night? Here's what you need to know

featuredLink.title: Cost-of-living relief is costing the budget $14.6 billion. Here's who is eligible for the support

children.content: If you weren't up frantically refreshing the blog all night (unlikely), here are a few of the key announcements you should know about:
There will be
$14.6 billion
of cost-of-living relief, including help with power bills, reduced health costs and creating more affordable housing
The government is allocating
$11.3 billion
to provide aged care workers with an interim increase of 15 per cent to award wages
An extra $40 per fortnight will be delivered for J
obSeeker, youth allowance
and
Austudy recipients
Bulk-billing incentives
will be tripled for the most common consultations with children under the age of 16, pensioners and other Commonwealth concession card holders
The maximum rate of Commonwealth Rent Assistance will be increased by
15 per cent

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Welcome to today's live blog, where we'll be unpacking last night's budget. Stick with us as we bring you the latest reactions, interviews and analysis from around the ABC.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Good morning!

children.content: Welcome to today's live blog, where we'll be unpacking last night's budget.
Stick with us as we bring you the latest reactions, interviews and analysis from around the ABC.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: "Independent Senator David Pocock describes that as both laughable and embarrassing. Are you to offer any such a small rise in JobSeeker?" Michael Rowland asks the prime minister. "There's a great contradiction you put in the first two issues you raised with me," Anthony Albanese says. "You said we're spending too much in your first question, and the second you say we're not spending enough. The truth is we got the balance right. "We understand that people are under pressure, but we needed to make sure that it was a responsible budget so this $40 increase is something that will make a difference to people."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'We got the balance right': PM responds to JobSeeker criticism

children.content: "Independent Senator
David Pocock
describes that as both laughable and embarrassing. Are you to offer any such a small rise in JobSeeker?"
Michael Rowland
asks the prime minister.
"There's a great contradiction you put in the first two issues you raised with me,"
Anthony Albanese
says.
"You said we're spending too much in your first question, and the second you say we're not spending enough. The truth is we got the balance right.
"We understand that people are under pressure, but we needed to make sure that it was a responsible budget so this $40 increase is something that will make a difference to people."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is currently speaking to Michael Rowland on News Breakfast. Rowland : "$20 billion in new spending, is that really going to help force the inflation dragon back into its cave?" Albanese : "$40 billion of savings over two budgets, 87% of the revenue gains put to the bottom line unlike our predecessors where the number was 40% or the Howard government where the number was 30%. This is a budget that takes pressure off families whilst not putting pressure on inflation."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Budget 'takes pressure off families whilst not putting pressure on inflation', PM says

children.content: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is currently speaking to Michael Rowland on News Breakfast.
Rowland
: "$20 billion in new spending, is that really going to help force the inflation dragon back into its cave?"
Albanese

: "$40 billion of savings over two budgets, 87% of the revenue gains put to the bottom line unlike our predecessors where the number was 40% or the Howard government where the number was 30%. This is a budget that takes pressure off families whilst not putting pressure on inflation."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: "We've got this big improvement in revenues in the near term and we've taken the most responsible approach to that and that's why we're forecasting a surplus for this year," he told News Breakfast. "But we've got some structural challenges in the budget. We made a heap of progress on those last night. But there will be more work to do. And again, as you said before, what we've been able to do on the foundations of a much more responsible and much stronger budget is to provide help for people doing it tough at the same time as we invest in the future."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Chalmers calls budget surplus a 'complex balancing act'

children.content: (ABC News)
"We've got this big improvement in revenues in the near term and we've taken the most responsible approach to that and that's why we're forecasting a surplus for this year," he told News Breakfast.

"But we've got some structural challenges in the budget. We made a heap of progress on those last night. But there will be more work to do. And again, as you said before, what we've been able to do on the foundations of a much more responsible and much stronger budget is to provide help for people doing it tough at the same time as we invest in the future."

image.altText: Trump mistakes rape accuser E Jean Carroll for former wife Marla Maples

items.synopsis: Donald Trump is found liable for sexual abuse, but not rape, in a civil trial brought by writer E Jean Carroll, who accused the former US president of raping her in the mid-1990s.

title.children: Donald Trump found liable for sexually abusing writer E Jean Carroll in civil trial

image.altText: Collage of scrabble letters spelling "W" and "L" and lightbulb, crane, cow, sheep and world icons..

items.synopsis: More money for JobSeeker, bulk-billing and spies, but more taxes on smokers and travellers. Find out who is up and who is down in the second federal budget delivered by Treasurer Jim Chalmers.

title.children: Find out if you're among the budget's winners or losers

image.altText: A female nurse in scrubs decorated with lovehearts administers a vaccine to a young toddler girl, being c

items.synopsis: The centrepiece of last night's federal budget is designed to reduce healthcare costs for some of Australia's most vulnerable people. So how much is it likely to help?

title.children: The government is tripling bulk-billing incentives to encourage free GP visits. Here's how it will work

image.altText: A composite image showing Wayne Swan handing down the budget in 2008 and Jim Chalmers handing down this budget.

items.synopsis: Jim Chalmers's second budget delivers a shift in the politics of the last 15 years, which have been dominated by relentless Coalition attacks on Labor's economic and fiscal record as a result of the budget blowout in the global financial crisis, writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: Chalmers's budget may only deliver one forecast surplus, but that's enough to bring on a political shift

image.altText: Victory Day tanks 2023

items.synopsis: Russia's annual Victory Day parade is ordinarily an impressive show of military might. This year, a lone vintage tank rattled through the Red Square.

title.children: 'Mauled in Ukraine': How Russia's annual Victory Day parade showed its losses to the world

image.altText: Police officer receives first aid beside police vehicle with smashed front window.

items.synopsis: Pakistani security forces arrest the former cricketer and national leader at Islamabad High Court, in a dramatic move that threatens fresh turmoil in the nuclear-armed country.

title.children: Imran Khan seized by dozens of police as violence breaks out in Pakistan

image.altText: The exterior of a Centrelink building and logo is seen in Sydney.

items.synopsis: Millions of people receiving Centrelink payments such as JobSeeker and rent assistance will see a boost after the federal budget goes through. Learn about what it means for you here.

title.children: If you get money from Centrelink, here's how the budget will affect you

image.altText: Collage with blue arrow pointing up, photo cut out of Jim Chalmers, pile of coins and red background.

items.synopsis: A modest increase in unemployment benefits and cheaper healthcare are the centrepieces of a federal budget tasked with helping the nation's most vulnerable at a time when living costs are hurting households.

title.children: Budget lifts JobSeeker and welfare payments as Labor posts a surplus

image.altText: A man in a hospital bed with thumbs up and cors and machines surrounding him, with a toy dog at the foot of the bed

items.synopsis: Jim Kneebone was in "complete shock" when he was diagnosed with early-stage pancreatic cancer. Here's what he wants you to know about early detection and how it could save your life.

title.children: Jim's fatigue and low iron levels hid a silent, growing killer, but some simple habits saved him

image.altText: Jason Moloney and Andrew Moloney pose by holding their fists forward standing next to each other

items.synopsis: Identical twin fighters with identical records, chasing identical dreams. Jason and Andrew Moloney face twin world title shots one week apart with the knowledge that this is their chance to achieve boxing immortality.

title.children: Identical twins with identical dreams: Moloneys set for career-defining world title fights

image.altText: A woman stands in a field of cotton.

items.synopsis: Lawyers and farmers say the government's response to the subsidence of land near gas projects is like a "bandaid on a volcano" and they have no confidence in its ability to tackle the problem.

title.children: Land is gradually sinking around gas projects, but the government says gas and farming can co-exist

image.altText: A line of huts sit on stilts in clear blue water with a white beach and mountains covered in trees in the background.

items.synopsis: The Albanese government is plunging almost two billion dollars into the Pacific as it tries to entrench Australia's position as the region's major security provider and expand diplomatic and economic links with island nations.

title.children: Budget: $2 billion to be plunged into Pacific nations to expand diplomatic and economic ties

image.altText: Jeremy Rockliff in a suit touches his finger tips together as he listens to someone speak during question time.

items.synopsis: Tasmania's opposition political parties have furiously opposed a move by the government which may restrict them from naming public servants under parliamentary privilege.

title.children: Backlash over push to limit free speech in Tasmanian Parliament

image.altText: a man with blood coming from his mouth after being hit

items.synopsis: Abusive spectators at any sport in New South Wales could face lifetime bans across all venues under a new policy to stamp out violence on the sidelines.

title.children: 'I was sickened': Move to ban violent spectators from all levels of sport

image.altText: Gerald Friessbourg, a middle aged man, sits in a recliner chair

items.synopsis: A public housing tenant unable to climb the stairs in his own property is pleading with authorities to move him, saying he sleeps in his armchair and is going weeks at a time without showering.

title.children: Public housing tenant unable to climb stairs going weeks without showering, sleeping in armchair

image.altText: A blue whale swims in the ocean.

items.synopsis: Blue whales are beginning their migration north to breed, but skinnier than usual animals spotted off Australia's coast are leaving researchers worried about their food source.

title.children: 'Skinny' blue whales spotted off Australia's coast worry researchers who think their food source is shrinking

image.altText: Jim Chalmers holds the budget while standing outside Parliament House

items.synopsis: Three huge structural shifts are pushing Australia's economy in a certain direction, writes Gareth Hutchens.

title.children: Care workers, climate change, and personal data. The budget says they're steering our economy

image.altText: cash lays on a kitchen table beside a cup of tea and a list of bills owing

items.synopsis: The federal budget includes billions in "targeted relief" for the most vulnerable Australians. Here's where the funds are going.

title.children: Cost-of-living relief is costing the budget $14.6 billion. Here's who is eligible for the support

image.altText: A white ute parked on a gravel drive in front of a sandstone work shed with an open roller door.

items.synopsis: Renewable energy and the transition away from fossil fuels are the government's key focus in its assistance to businesses, big and small, but a key small business tax break has been scaled back.

title.children: Renewables, electrification, tax breaks and 'less about utes': What's in the budget for business

image.altText: Katy Gallagher and Jim Chalmers walking past the budget tree

items.synopsis: High-vis has been replaced, as a budgetary favourite, with people who for some time have been a bit low-vis — aged care workers, single parents and renters, writes Annabel Crabb.

title.children: Budgets are about choices and Jim Chalmers's are obvious: Truck Man out, poorest Australians in

image.altText: Charred remains of scooters and trees after an air strike.

items.synopsis: Human Rights Watch says Myanmar's military used an "enhanced-blast" munition known as a fuel-air explosive in an airstrike that killed more than 160 people.

title.children: Myanmar's military used thermobaric bomb in attack that killed 40 kids: Human Rights Watch

image.altText: Tom Seymour in a suit and a tie speaking on stage at the AFR Summit.

items.synopsis: PricewaterhouseCoopers Australia chief executive Tom Seymour stands down as the consulting firm feels the fallout of a partner betraying the trust of its biggest client: the federal government.

title.children: PwC CEO steps down after tax documents leak scandal

image.altText: A man in a pink shirt.

items.synopsis: Autopsies on corpses found in mass graves linked to a religious cult in Kenya reveal missing organs, and raising suspicions of forced harvesting, investigators say.

title.children: Missing organs in Kenya cult victims lead to harvesting fears

image.altText: A man nearing middle age, with short dark hair and a "soul patch" under his lip, sits on a plane with earbuds in his ears.

items.synopsis: Paramedics tell a coronial inquest in NSW that "no-one was interested" in the fact that they were trying to save a man's life in a "weird" scene that an expert witness said "sounded very disturbing".

title.children: Frog poison inquest hears spiritual retreat crowd kept doing yoga while 46yo died

image.altText: Vladmir Putin standing at a lectern, surrounded by people in formal uniforms.

items.synopsis: In a 10-minute speech in Red Square, Mr Putin repeated familiar messages he has delivered many times in the nearly 15 months of Russia's war in Ukraine.

title.children: Putin says a 'real war' is being waged against Russia in Victory Day speech

image.altText: View from inside a car of a flooded road.

items.synopsis: Schools are evacuated, roads and parks are flooded and people are being told to prepare to leave homes in case of flash flooding around New Zealand.

title.children: Student missing in a cave as Auckland declares state of emergency

image.altText: Shane walks along carrying documents and wearing sunglasses.

items.synopsis: ACT Director of Public Prosecutions Shane Drumgold called police officers investigating the alleged rape of Brittany Higgins "boofheads", Bruce Lehrmann's lawyer tells an inquiry.

title.children: ACT top prosecutor allegedly labelled police investigators 'boofheads' during Bruce Lehrmann's trial

image.altText: Two little girls smile as they play with a bucket of foam, which has gotten all up their arms.

items.synopsis: Kiya Gill's young daughter has difficulties with her legs, but living 350 kilometres away from the nearest town, she believes it took longer to realise her development was different to other kids'.

title.children: Kiya worried she'd failed her family, but she says a playgroup in her remote community could have helped

image.altText: Powelines surrounded by trees and shrubs fill a sunrise sky.

items.synopsis: Western Australia’s biggest electricity system will need to roughly triple in size over the next two decades, as the state seeks to wean itself off fossil fuels and go green.

title.children: Perth needs to generate 10 times more power than it currently does if we’re to go green

image.altText: A WA Police logo on evidence bags containing large amounts of cash.

items.synopsis: West Australian police have charged a 36-year-old man with property laundering after seizing $1.8 million in cash during a traffic stop near Southern Cross last week, as investigations continue.

title.children: Police suspect $1.8 million seized in West Australian traffic stop is the profits of drug trafficking

image.altText: A shark with a fish in its mouth.

items.synopsis: Fishers say they're losing more and more fish to sharks. While some are calling for increased fishing quotas or culls, researchers say there's no simple answer.

title.children: 'I lost 125 fish to sharks': Anglers say they're encountering more sharks than ever. So what do the numbers tell us?
